fields.headline: Life of a playwright
fields.bodyText: October 17 1915 Born to prosperous Polish Jewish immigrant parents in New York. The family wealth, built on clothing manufacture, is destroyed in the 1930s Depression. 1934 - 1938 Studies journalism at the University of Michigan, where he begins to write and stage plays. 1940: Marries college girlfriend Mary Slattery, with whom he will have two children. He is exempted from military service in the second world war because of a sporting injury. 1944 The Man Who Had All The Luck opens on Broadway. Critically panned, it is pulled after only four performances. 1947 All My Sons named best play of the year by the New York Drama Critics' circle. 1949 Death of a Salesman wins the Pulitzer prize, and three Tony awards. 1953 The Crucible opens on Broadway. 1956 Called by the House Un-American Activities Committee during the communist witch-hunts. Elia Kazan had identified him as a sympathiser. Divorces Mary Slattery, and marries Marilyn Monroe. 1957 Convicted of contempt of Congress for failing to name communist sympathisers. The conviction is appealed and overturned in the following year. 1961 The Misfits, a Clark Gable film for which Miller wrote the screenplay, is released. Miller and Monroe divorce. 1962 Marries photographer Inge Morath. They have a son and daughter. The daughter, Rebecca, born in 1962, will later become a writer and film-maker. 1985 Cuts short a visit to Turkey in support of English playwright Harold Pinter, who had criticised the Turkish government's human rights record. 1987 Publishes autobiography Timebends: A Life. 2002 He wins the Principe de Asturias literary prize. His wife Inge Morath dies. December 2004 Announces plans to marry Agnes Barley, a 34-year-old artist. February 2005 Dies at home in Roxbury, Connecticut.
